name: Kepler-367
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-367 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-367 is a star with 0.585 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.69 times its radius. It is located 616.60 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-367 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-367 b

Kepler-367 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.20 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 37.82 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-367.

The mass of Kepler-367 b is 1.81 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-367 b is 1.3 that of Earth. At 1.81 Earth masses, Kepler-367 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-367 c

Kepler-367 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.25 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 53.58 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-367.

The mass of Kepler-367 c is 1.49 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-367 c is 1.2 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-367 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

With a semi-major axis of 0.253 astronomical units, and a mass of 1.49 Earth masses, Kepler-367 c could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-367, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
